action.action-desc: Mr. Ellison (for himself, Ms. Norton, Ms. Maxine Waters of California, Ms. Schakowsky, Ms. Jayapal, Mr. Blumenauer, and Ms. Shea-Porter) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To establish privacy protections for customers of broadband Internet access service and other telecommunications services.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Online Privacy Act.

section.header: Privacy of customers of broadband Internet access service and other telecommunications services

subsection.text: Section 222 of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. 222) is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating subsection (h) as subsection (i); and
by inserting after subsection (g) the following:

subsection.header: Privacy of customers of broadband Internet access service and other telecommunications services

subparagraph.text: the term broadband Internet access service has the meaning given the term in section 8.2 of title 47, Code of Federal Regulations, or any successor regulation;

clause.text: a current or former subscriber to a telecommunications service; or
an applicant for a telecommunications service;

subparagraph.text: the term customer proprietary information means, with respect to information or content that a telecommunications carrier acquires in connection with its provision of telecommunications service—

clause.text: individually identifiable customer proprietary network information;
personally identifiable information; and
content of communications;

subparagraph.text: the term opt-in approval means a method for a telecommunications carrier to obtain customer consent to use, disclose, or permit access to the customer's customer proprietary information that requires that the telecommunications carrier obtain from the customer affirmative, express consent allowing the requested usage, disclosure, or access to the customer proprietary information after the customer is provided appropriate notification of the carrier’s request;
the term sensitive customer proprietary information includes—

clause.text: financial information;
health information;
information pertaining to children;
Social Security numbers;
precise geolocation information;
content of communications;
call detail information;
web browsing history, application usage history, and the functional equivalents of either; and
any other customary proprietary information that the Commission determines to be sensitive; and

subparagraph.text: the term telecommunications service includes broadband Internet access service and interconnected VoIP service.

paragraph.text: In carrying out this section, the Commission shall promulgate regulations to protect the privacy of customers of telecommunications service.
In promulgating regulations under paragraph (2), the Commission shall—

subparagraph.text: require a telecommunications carrier to notify a customer about the collection, use, and sharing of his or her customer proprietary information, including by—

clause.text: notifying the customer about the types of customer proprietary information the carrier collects;
specifying how and for what purposes the carrier uses and shares customer proprietary information; and
identifying the types of entities with which the carrier shares customer proprietary information;
provide the notification under subparagraph (A) to a customer at the point of sale, before the purchase of service; and
update a customer when the carrier makes a material change to a privacy policy, including any of the policies described in subparagraph (A);

subparagraph.text: require a telecommunications carrier to obtain opt-in approval from a customer to use and share his or her sensitive customer proprietary information;
implement strong protection for de-identified customary proprietary information, to prevent re-identifying such information;

prohibit a telecommunications carrier from refusing to serve a customer who does not consent to the use and sharing of his or her customer proprietary information for commercial purposes (commonly known as take-it-or-leave-it offers); and

clause.text: develop reasonable data security practices; and
notify customers if a breach of security has occurred.

paragraph.text: not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, shall promulgate regulations under section 222(h)(2) of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. 222(h)(2)), as added by subsection (a); and
shall ensure that the regulations promulgated under paragraph (1) take effect not later than 180 days after the date of promulgation.
